options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the history of Kurdistan and Kurdish studies. Later in the course, we delved into specific topics concerning Kurdistan, such as feminism. art, and the political economy. I learned more about the Kurds outside of conflict situations.

This class developed two important knowledge bases for me: one was about Kurdistan, and the other was about decolonizing methodologies. You're simply not going to have a ton of classes on Kurdistan in general, and so this class was rather special that way in that we got a Kurdish perspective on events in the region. And we learned about colonization and colonies and what that means!
I learned so much about the Kurds, their origin, their culture, and their fight for liberation. I also learned about decolonization and decolonizing methodologies.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course had many interesting and helpful readings and we had many brilliant guest speakers. We had considerable freedom with our presentations and final essays, so we could explore our interests. The course had a wide breadth but I still feel like I learned a lot. However, we did not have many discussions and it was often a lecture and occasionally off-topic. I think it could be improved by adding more structure and making sure everyone knows what is going to happen in each class, such as planned activities or a new class format. The reading load is also quite heavy, though we don't always end up discussing everything.

Strengths: great professor who cares, somewhat engaged students 

Weaknesses: it was on Zoom and that made focusing occasionally hard; too much reading

The course draws from many readings by scholars who are actually Kurdish, and there were great guest speakers who led insightful discussions with their research. There were a lot of readings, though they will probably be cut down for the next time the class is taught. Despite this, the readings never felt like they were pointless, and the fact that there weren't very many assignments made it manageable. Overall, the class was really amazing.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Success: we met up, reading responses kept us on our toes

Weaknesses: occasionally too much (difficult) reading made it hard to keep up with the class

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course if someone was interested in Kurdistan. I truly learned a lot and Professor Kurt is an interesting and brilliant man. It was not always my favorite style of course, as it was a lot of lecturing and personal anecdotes, but I still learned from it.
I would. It was a ton of reading, and that was tough, but it is seldom you get the opportunity to take a wonderful class with a professor such as Mehmet Kurt.

I would absolutely take this course. It's probably the only class available in the US that so comprehensively examines the Kurdish people and decolonization. In certain countries, people can be sent to prison (or worse) for teaching or taking a class like this, and the fact that Professor Kurt can combine scholarship with lived experience is really valuable. Take this class if you can! Even if you have no prior background in Middle Eastern studies or Anthropology.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
